newsitem.title: USA: CSCE nearby coffee stumbles on Colombian news.
newsitem.headline: CSCE nearby coffee stumbles on Colombian news.

text.p: CSCE nearby coffee futures ended sharply lower in volatile trading on Wednesday, amid a perception that the upcoming release of Colombian coffee could help alleviate near-term supply tightness, dealers said.

Colombian Finance Minister Jose Antonio Ocampo said late Tuesday the government was opening "unlimited" coffee registrations for July to August, a period in which he said the country was expected to export 2.5 million 60-kg bags of coffee.
"It is bearish because it implies there is more coffee available," said Refco Inc. analyst Ann Prendergast. "And the market has been running up on tight supply."

The benchmark July contract tumbled 12.65 cents per lb, to 251.55 cents, after ranging between 264.50 and 250.00 cents. Second-month September fell 7.95 cents, to 225.10 cents, while the back months closed 6.15 lower to 2.50 higher.
The July/September spread, a barometer of nearby availability, shrank to 26.45 cents from 31.15 cents at the close on Tuesday.
Despite today's sell-off on the Colombian news, some analysts said the market may reacted too strongly as stockpiles were still hovering near 20-year lows.

"I don't think it is as bearish as some people think," said Merrill Lynch analyst Judith Ganes. "There is too much emphasis on the unlimited exports, but there might not be an unlimited amount of coffee to sell."

Coffee prices gapped sharply lower at the outset, but the market managed to bounce into positive territory on a round of nervous weather-related buying amid cool weather outlooks this weekend in top-grower Brazil.
Brazilian weather services on Wednesday forecasted a cold weekend for the country's key coffee regions, with temperatures possibly dropping to critical levels.
But Smith Barney meterologist Jon Davis said Wednesday that there is little threat of any frost or freeze damage to Brazil's coffee-growing areas during the next 10 days.
Refco's Prendergast said two key factors seen influencing the market in the next few weeks were Brazil's weather and its crop prospects for the approaching 1997/98 harvest.
On Wednesday, Brazil's largest co-operative said the country's coffee crop should reach 24 to 25 million 60-kg bags in 1997/98, down from recent estimates of 27 to 30 million bags in 1996/97.
His estimate was within earlier trade expectations, but well above other Brazilian forecasts of 20 million bags or below.
Another factor seen impacting the market was the drop in total open interest, which has fallen from a recent peak of some 45,000 lots in March to 27,537 lots as of June 3.
Although Prendergast noted some of the drop in open interest was due to an increase in margins, she said that combined with thinner turnover it appeared bearish.
"Falling open interest and falling volume is a warning signal," said Prendergast. "It indicates a weakening market."
